Award.AwardTitle: Lehigh ADVANCE: Building Community Beyond Academic Departments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Lehigh University ADVANCE IT project focuses on institutional transformation at a medium-sized private research university with interdisciplinary collaboration at its core. It is expected that the focus on interdisciplinarity, highly characteristic of institutions of this size, will serve to provide a means for implementing evaluation, mentoring and networking policies and programs.

Intellectual Merit. The LU ADVANCE IT project is novel in that it links ADVANCE activities with interdisciplinary collaboration, a widely used practice at this institution. Thus this project will answer important questions including the role of promotion criteria and procedures when interdisciplinarity is emphasized. The LU ADVANCE program is firmly rooted in the social science literature, which contributes to understanding how culture, policy and practice are interrelated.

Broader Impact. The Lehigh University ADVANCE IT project will focus on regional workshops and networking opportunities. As such, this project has the potential to impact institutions beyond the funded campus. It is expected that dissemination of project findings will occur broadly through traditional means. Also, as a result of regional networks, it is expected that this ADVANCE project will serve as a model for other institutions of similar type and size.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lehigh University is a private, mid-sized, research-intensive university located in Bethlehem, PA.  Lehigh ADVANCE: Building Community Across Academic Departments (NSF ADVANCE Institutional Transformation (IT) grant) was funded in 2010 to improve recruitment, retention, career satisfaction, and leadership development of early- to mid-career women faculty in STEM while examining how interdisciplinary organization impacts the work environment for women STEM faculty. By adapting or creating best practices, programs, and policies for interdisciplinary research and teaching environments, Lehigh ADVANCE has contributed to knowledge about what works for women STEM faculty in similar institutional contexts.

ADVANCE is recognized by STEM faculty for raising awareness of the issues faced by women in STEM, providing a platform for identifying solutions and supporting campus-wide dialogue about diversity, equity, and inclusion. Evaluation demonstrates ADVANCE’s role in increasing the number of women faculty in STEM; harmonizing and strengthening the processes and outcomes for hiring and dual career challenges; establishing a vibrant community of STEM women instituting more effective networking and mentoring programs for pre- and post-tenure women; contributing to interdisciplinary hiring and promotion guidelines; improving transparency of promotion criteria on campus; and closing gender-gaps in general indicators of job satisfaction. Since the inception of LU ADVANCE, the number of women tenure-track faculty in STEM has increased by 45% from fall 2010 (N=40) to fall 2015 (N=58), compared to a 2% increase in men tenure-track faculty over the same time period (fall 2010 N=203, fall 2015 N=207).  Women comprised 41% of all new STEM faculty hired between 2010 and 2015. Additionally, the number of STEM women at the assistant and full professor ranks has increased — assistant professors by 101% (fall 2010 N=11, fall 2015 N=23) and full professors by 43% (fall 2010 N=14, fall 2015 N=20). These results were achieved through multiple interventions at each layer of the university organization and with strong support from the senior leadership. Each program has a multi-disciplinary component and was informed by the research and program evaluation.

ADVANCE studied 10 institutions’ STEM faculty and found that while there may be little gender difference associated with the desire to work in interdisciplinary and collaborative ways, women may perceive this work as risky. Working in interdisciplinary academic programs contributes to job satisfaction, although the department climate remains a crucial component impacting how women faculty experience their overall work environment.  For women, tokenism in the department is strongly correlated with ratings of isolation, unfairness, and inequity at the institution level. Moreover, the work-climate for women in STEM is not perceived equally across all disciplines:  men engineers report greater satisfaction compared to women engineers, and women engineers are less satisfied than women scientists, where women are more represented. To minimize the perceptions of risk, institution level support for interdisciplinarity must be present. Additionally, in terms of scholarly productivity, preliminary research suggests there is a smaller gender gap in publication productivity, and when there is a male advantage, it is observed among those faculty categorized as highly productive. Thus, it was important that the ADVANCE initiatives helped foster community across disciplines, increase opportunities for the standards of successful careers to be communicated, and identify specific disciplines or layers of the organization which may require additional attention to see long-term changes.

Intellectual merit of this activity is demonstrated in several ways. First, the knowledge about implicit bias, recruitment best practices, improvements in networking and mentoring, and building inclusive culture has reached beyond gender-studies or STEM faculty. Progress in STEM fields is evidence that positive change is possible across campus. Second, the research yields important insight for developing programs or policies to support the increased participation and advancement of women in STEM while universities continue towards interdisciplinary pursuits. Third, the evaluation yields knowledge about what works for, and how to improve, the implementation of programs and policies to support women in STEM, especially those in interdisciplinary contexts.

Lehigh ADVANCE’s influence reached beyond the campus community to have a broader impact through trainings, presentations, workshops, symposia, posters, and publications about the research and successful programs. Work has been disseminated via diverse venues, including ADVANCE annual meetings, Women Engineering ProActive Network, American Society of Engineering Education, a featured article in AWIS magazine, the Indo-US Science and Technology Forum, the 8th European Conference on Gender Equality in Higher Education in Vienna, in New York through the University of Cologne-German House, a Patriot League Symposium, and the Lehigh Valley Inter-regional Networking and Connecting Consortium. Lehigh ADVANCE reached numerous professionals in government agencies, higher education, sociology, organizational management, business, law, and human resources. The multiple networks of influence are all critical to transforming the culture of STEM, for research and teaching collaboration, and for attracting young engineers and scientists to academic careers.

Overall, ADVANCE has been a transformative force across campus and will be sustained through institutional support as a Center within the Provost Office.
